message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the patient has Alport syndrome, which is caused by a genetic defect in type IV collagen. Option B is associated with membranous nephropathy, option C is associated with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, and option D is associated with IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest glomerulonephritis, and among the options, only defective type IV collagen is associated with Alport syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the kidneys and often causes glomerulonephritis. The family history of kidney disease and sensorineural hearing loss further support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including recurrent episodes of swelling and a family history of kidney disease, suggest Alport syndrome, which is caused by defective type IV collagen. The other options are associated with other renal diseases such as membranous nephropathy or IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and medical history suggest Alport syndrome, which is caused by a genetic defect in type IV collagen. This defect can lead to kidney disease, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities. Phospholipase A2 receptor antibody is associated with membranous nephropathy. Prior streptococcal infection is associated with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Vascular IgA deposits are associated with IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of red urine, recurrent swelling, and hearing loss suggest Alport syndrome, which is most commonly caused by a defective type IV collagen. The other options are associated with different types of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Alport syndrome, which is caused by defective type IV collagen. The episodes of swelling and the family history of kidney disease also support this diagnosis. Phospholipase A2 receptor antibody is associated with membranous nephropathy. Prior streptococcal infection is associated with post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Vascular IgA deposits are associated with IgA nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and family history suggest Alport syndrome, which is caused by a genetic defect in type IV collagen. This defect leads to glomerular basement membrane thickening, which causes hematuria and progressive renal failure. Options B, C, and D are all associated with different types of glomerulonephritis, but the presentation of this patient fits with Alport syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including intermittent red urine, hearing loss, and a family history of kidney disease, suggest Alport syndrome, which is caused by a defective type IV collagen. The other options relate to different forms of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recurrent episodes of swelling of face and feet, along with the family history of kidney disease, suggest Alport syndrome, which is caused by a genetic defect in type IV collagen. The presence of red urine and hematuria also supports this diagnosis. Phospholipase A2 receptor antibody and prior streptococcal infection are associated with membranous nephropathy and IgA nephropathy, respectively. Vascular IgA deposits are associated with Henoch-Schonlein purpura.
